    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, this Bill is purely an administrative Bill. The main purpose of this Bill is to give the Rural Board power to levy an improvement rate in the areas excised from the City Council, such as Katong and Braddell Heights, when these areas are transferred to the Rural Board on 1st January, 1959.

    As the Ordinance stands at present, the improvement rate can only be levied in the City. In the new Planning Bill, there is provision for all local authorities to levy an improvement rate in their areas.

Column: 1306

However, the Planning Bill will not be in force by the time the Rural Board takes over these new areas on the 1st of January, 1959.

    As regards Katong and Braddell Heights, the City Council at present levies an improvement rate in these areas, and it is considered that the rate should continue to be levied when the Rural Board takes over.

    There is also provision in the Bill for the Minister to exempt any areas from payment of an improvement rate. It is therefore proposed that, for the time being, exemption should be given in respect of Ulu Pandan and Pasir Panjang when the Rural Board hands them over to the City Council on 1st January, 1959. An improvement rate is not at present levied in these areas.

    These provisions of which I have spoken are contained in clause 3 of the Bill. Clauses 2 and 4 and the Schedule are all consequential amendments.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Assembly immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. [Dato Abdul Hamid].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read the Third time and passed.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to take this opportunity to place on record the wonderful job done by the Public Service Commission.     Sir, the Chief Minister's post in any democratic country is a post of honour. People select him because of the services he has rendered to the country. This has happened in India, Burma, Ceylon and many other countries where they have had to fight for their freedom. Similarly with the other Ministers. Here, of course, with the progress of time, the colonial powers - the United Kingdom is the only colonial power left in the Far East - are giving us constitutional progress, and we have now come to the stage of internal self-government.

    Sir, the Chief Minister's post carries a salary comparable to that of the Chief Secretary, and the Chief Justice - he is above them. But let me explain further. As I have said in my speech on the Budget the salary structure is too high. The local man has not got to run two homes. He stays in his home. He might possibly be shifted in future to a different one, i.e. the Government provide residence and other benefits. Sir, I would suggest that as we are replacing the White men with our local men, their salaries should be fixed by the incoming Government per local requirements. I also want to know who is going to fix the salary of the Prime Minister of the incoming Government and whether the salary of the present Chief Minister will be allowed to continue. I would suggest that the incoming Government consider my points in the interests of the taxpayers. They should not pay the Chief Minister the maximum for such a post of honour, but should reduce his salary and the salaries of the Ministers as well to suit the local needs.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Chairman, Sir, when the Rendel Constitution came into force, there was nothing in the Budget regarding payments of salaries to be made to Ministers and, therefore, the first Government which came into office under that Constitution had to consider

Column: 1311

what salaries were fair for Ministers. A motion was brought before this House in 1955 and the salaries suggested by the Council of Ministers were adopted by this Assembly. If I remember rightly, it was even pointed out by one Member of the Opposition that the Government was rather cautious in its recommendations, and that particular Member of the Opposition felt that the salary of $3,500 for the Chief Minister of Singapore was, in his view, inadequate.

    Be that as it may, Sir, in reply to the hon. Member for Telok Ayer, may I say to him that when the new Constitution comes into force next year, it will be the Assembly which will have to fix the remuneration of the Prime Minister. For the present, while it may appear to the hon. Member that $3,500 is rather high, may I point out to him that out of 12 months' salary, two months' salary is being paid out as income tax?

    Mr Wong Foo Nam: I am afraid I am unable to agree with the Member for Telok Ayer. Sir, the Chief Minister's post is very important. We can say that it is an honour to whoever holds that post. But a man cannot do the work if he is incapable. The Chief Minister has a lot of responsibilities and he has entertainment expenses which I do not think he would like to charge to the Government, although he is entitled to term the expenses as "official". There are also contributions and other expenses which he could not really charge to the Government. Therefore, if the salary of $3,500 appears to the Member for Telok Ayer to be excessive, may I ask him what he considers an ordinary professional man should earn?

    The Chairman: Order. I think hon. Members are doing exactly what they are not supposed to do in Committee of Supply. In Committee of Supply, the debate is really on the general principles of Government policy. A debate of this nature, of course, could be properly conducted in the Estimates Committee.

    As I have always pointed out in the past, I have permitted hon. Members to ventilate what they think ought to be

ventilated, and that is all, but a debate should not develop around those subjects.

    The Chairman: Order. I thought I did indicate that I am stopping the debate on this particular item.

    Mr Wong Foo Nam: I consider the amount of salary for the Chief Minister should not be less than $3,500.

    The Chairman: Order. I think the hon. Member should now stop at that.

    The Chairman: We are on the Chief Minister!

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: I am so sorry. Sir.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, on the amendment moved by the Member for Telok Ayer on the salary of the Chief Minister, I personally do not consider that it is too much or too little. If the Chief Minister has done a good job, he deserves all that he earns and more - he also deserves our gratitude. If the job is not done properly then we know what our feelings should be towards him.

    Sir, on the subject of the Chief Minister's office, I have noticed that for three long years the Chief Minister has also been the Minister for Labour and Welfare and that the Chief Minister's post is one without a portfolio.

    However, I notice that this year there is going to be added another department called the Rural Development Department with a Commissioner appointed. I think not only are Members in this House grateful for that appointment, but also all the people in Singapore, especially those in the rural areas. It is a long time since anybody mentioned the rural areas. Attention has been focussed on the city and the rural folks have been left to do what they can for themselves and with whatever means

Column: 1313

they have at their command. In fact, in comparing the Rural Board to the City Council, I think the Rural Board is a very poor cousin, one of the very poor relatives who are always living from hand to mouth, holding out their hands and begging for money and then finding that not much is forthcoming, or what is coming will never be sufficient for any project. The people in the city live in houses made of brick, mortar and stones and supplied with modern sanitation, but the people in the rural areas live in attap huts. While the people in the city have good, well-lighted and well-metalled roads to move about, the people in the rural areas must content themselves with moving along unmade-up roads, or even roads that are almost impassable. Bridges in the city area may cost as much as a few million dollars, whereas in the rural areas you may still find the one-log bridge - the trunk of a coconut tree felled and placed across a river or stream to form a bridge. We find that the health problem in the city is well looked after, with many clinics spotted all over the place, whereas in the rural areas they are few and far between. Sir, all these are just a few of the examples of how the rural people have always been treated by the Government.

10.30 a.m.

    Today, as we look through the whole Budget we find that the Chief Minister has remembered the rural people. He has appointed a Commissioner to deal directly with the problem of rural development. I am sure this scheme is going to help the rural folks in giving them more amenities. I am aware that work has already been started, and that roads are being made. Many of the unemployed are finding this Department a useful means of gaining their self-respect, by earning their money instead of getting it from the Social Welfare Department. But I would like the Chief Minister to remember that not only is the work that is in progress important and must be carried out but that more of such work must be done. Work should be selected from all areas in Singapore

Column: 1314

based on population concentration and requirements with a view to long-term development. I would also urge the Chief Minister to make known to the people the nature of this work, and that the people should actively co-operate with the Government to help themselves. I would like to see a scheme whereby the Government is identified with the people. I would like to see it not only welcomed and praised by the people but that the people should show their willingness to co-operate with the Government by coming out and contributing what they can for their own welfare.

    Let me take an example, Sir. Suppose we have a stretch of road that must be repaired. I do not want to see just the Government coming along with their employees repairing that stretch of road and then going away quietly. It does not give the people a feeling that something is being done especially for them. I would like to see the request coming from the people for making up or repairing of roads or bridges and that it be channelled to the Commissioner of Rural Development. Thereafter, there may be a conference between government officers and the people concerned, and a plan drawn up whereby the people will assist the Government in pointing out those places that need repair. Those who can come along to help voluntarily will come forward to help in that capacity, thus showing that they are not helping because they are paid, but because they have a sense of civic responsibility. Then also, they could, by discussion between them and the Government, get the Government away from the usual red tape of doing exactly what the people do not want them to do, and do instead the right thing. In fact, I know many projects where Government officials want to implement their pet schemes without consulting the people, and they ended in failure. Here is an opportunity for great participation, where the people can be consulted and where they can give their best ideas to the Government.

    Sir, I am only quoting an example of road building or road repairing. There are other things the Government can do.

Column: 1315

Perhaps Government can assist the people in large scale fruit plantation. Perhaps we may have Government loaning out tractors for ploughing agricultural areas, and in that way save a lot of trouble for the people. Perhaps the Government may assist the people in poultry and pig rearing. Government may perhaps be able to give these hard-working rural folks a new store. Or Government may be able to give them poultry, cattle, goats or pigs in order to breed better strains and in order to increase their production. I think a host of these things can be done for the people if the Government will go to them.

    I would like, of course, the Chief Minister to let us know more details about these schemes, especially in this Assembly, so that they may be conveyed to the people and the people will know that the Government are going all out to help them, and help them in the right way.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not want to repeat what I already said on the Second Reading on Friday; but on this subject of the Rural Development Panel which the hon. Member for Serangoon has brought up - the Commissioner and the members on his Panel - I would like to ask the Chief Minister how he reconciles the decentralisation of local government, which is going to go forward through the District Councils, with the centralisation in the opposite direction which is being proposed through this new Panel. I would refer again to page 466 of the Estimates, to the notes on the Head which we are discussing at this moment; the reference to the fact that the "activities of various Departments and organisations concerned with the rural areas have tended to be unco-ordinated in the past"; and this co-ordination which is to be brought about through the setting up of the Rural Development Panel, consisting of the Heads of Departments concerned with rural development - a purely Government Department. As I pointed out on Friday, there is no reference to District Councillors or Chairman of District Councils being represented on this Panel, so that

Column: 1316

the District Councils elected through the people can be brought into close touch with this centralisation scheme. As I already elaborated on Friday - and I do not want to do it again - I do suggest that we should give very serious thought to making an entirely fresh appraisal of the way in which our administration is being carried out, for we cannot afford various Councils at various levels - Government (or national), City Council and District Councils. Will the Chief Minister not agree that the expenses involved should be looked into afresh so that we might possibly streamline our administration for a very small island much more inexpensively and, at the same time, more efficiently?

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to remind the hon. Member for Telok Ayer about what he said on the question of the Chief Minister's salary, when that question was originally brought up. I am not sure whether you have closed the question on the debate.

    The Chairman: Order. I have, in fact, closed the debate on the salary itself. The debate can of course be pursued, as I have indicated.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, Sir, rural development is a very important part of any elected Government's activities in any country. Our rural areas happen to be not very big compared with the rural areas in most countries which have a large land mass. Perhaps it is for that reason that rural development has been neglected in the past. I personally think that the real reason why rural development was neglected in the past is because the Government in those days was mainly interested in Singapore's progress as a commercial centre, and therefore the concentration on development was more on the city itself, which played a part in the commercial development of Singapore. Not much interest was therefore taken in the rural areas which were not directly contributing to the commercial progress of Singapore.

Column: 1317



    Things have changed, Sir, since the last few years. Rural development now assumes a more important role in our economy, because the commercial progress of Singapore is slowly dwindling, with the result that we have to rely more and more on our home production and cut down on imports. For that reason, Sir, I have always advocated that the development of the rural areas should receive better encouragement from the Government, so that we may be able to produce more of our own foodstuffs at home and thereby depend less on imported foodstuffs, and spend less money on imported foodstuffs. The progress made because of rural development has been phenomenal in the last three years, as I have often stated in this House and outside. We have been able to achieve remarkable progress in poultry rearing. Production of poultry has increased from 5 million to 25 million.

    Our rural development assistance consists of three phases. In the first phase, attention has been given to the elimination of risk which the fanner would normally, take because of the disease factor in the livestock. Once that risk is lessened, then the farmer would proceed to go into livestock production in a big way.

    The second factor is that farmers should be given the advantage of scientific knowledge which has been accrued over the years, and, therefore, the second phase is to give them that knowledge through research work carried out in Singapore by specialists.

    The third phase will be to encourage the farmer to enter the export market and thereby create a new industry for Singapore. We should earn money by these exports.

    There again research is important. It should also be part of Government's policy to carry out further research in order not only to eliminate the disease factor in poultry rearing, but also to cut down the cost and the time of production, so that the ultimate cost would

Column: 1318

be cheaper, and therefore the farmer would be able to compete in the export market. In fact, that is what is happening now.

    We are now not only self-sufficient in pigs, about 60 per cent of which used to be imported in 1955, but we are actually exporting them to neighbouring countries.

10.45 a.m.

    Sir, reference was made by the Member for Tanglin to a statement in the Budget that rural development was not co-ordinated in the past. That was so, Sir, because rural development consists of various aspects which were being handled by different Ministries.

    For instance, land alienation and resettlement were in the hands of the Ministry of Local Government, Lands and Housing; the development of roads and bridges was in the hands of the Ministry of Communications and Works; assistance to farmers in the raising of livestock and agricultural production, the use of fertilisers, germicides and so on, were in the hands of my Ministry.

    Now, that would mean that three or four Ministries were handling rural development from different aspects. It was necessary to have a co-ordinating body to centralize the work, so that all aspects of rural development would go hand in hand and the whole project would not lag behind because one aspect had lagged behind. That is why the Government decided last year to form a Rural Development Panel and, as I explained to the House last year, it was thought that the best person to co-ordinate the activities of the various Ministries would be the Chief Minister. He could then issue directives to the Ministries concerned, saying, "I want this aspect to forge ahead", and could ask questions as to why one aspect was not going ahead, thereby holding up other rural development work, and so on.

    Sir, the Member for Tanglin also raised another point - why no reference was made to District Councils playing a part in rural development.

Column: 1319



    The fact that they were not mentioned does not mean that they will not be consulted, but since the rural development envisaged in the Budget is a matter of Government expenditure out of the public revenue, that is, Government revenue, it is only fit that the Panel should consist of Government department heads. But it is quite clear that wherever any matter concerns the District Councils, the Rural Development Commissioner would consult them and get their opinion on the subject. Any definite decision has got to be made only by the Panel because it is Government money that is being spent.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, I would not like it to be thought - and I think my hon, friend who has just spoken rather implied it - that I was against centralisation, the Rural Development Panel and the necessity of having a co-ordinating body for improving our rural areas. I am very much in favour of them. But in these days of economic difficulties, I think we' should consider whether we can afford the luxury of having so many administrative bodies on a small island, and whether we should not think afresh about greater centralisation rather than greater decentralisation of local government - which is the way in which we are moving at present. It is not too late for us to reconsider and give a further appraisal to this whole problem. It has been sparked off, I think, by the fact that the Government have found it necessary to set up this Panel to look after the interests of local farmers and the people living and working in the rural areas.

    Sir, there are many problems connected with development of our livestock production and our egg production. There has been an enormous advance in the last few years, and it has been a very welcome one. At the same time, it has its dangers and its difficulties.

    I think the Minister for Commerce and Industry will agree with me that egg production has probably dropped in the last six or nine months, the reason being that, because of the enormous increase in egg production, the price of eggs has dropped, I think, from 14 or 13 cents to something like 10 cents.

Column: 1320

That is because there has been overproduction. A lot of the farmers in the rural areas are fighting shy of going in for poultry because of this drop. They are unable to make both ends meet in keeping poultry. As a result of this, the price of eggs has begun to rise again and perhaps found its economic level somewhere around 13 cents.

    Now, the problem here - maybe the Minister can inform us - is whether we can cheapen feeding stuffs for poultry, so that the price of eggs can drop and the farmers can make a living. That is the crux of the whole problem. In the good old days, as we sometimes call them, there was the kampong hen which could scratch around wherever it liked in the neighbourhood of the village, eating whatever there was off the ground, and it produced one egg a week. You can call that pure gain. Now that our new methods are concentrated methods, possibly a hen could produce four eggs a week, but if it costs three and a half eggs in foodstuffs to produce them it is not pure gain.

    That is the problem with which we are faced in Singapore, and it is one which certainly requires a Rural Development Panel to look into and to centralise all our methods.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, I am glad that my amendment has aroused so much discussion. When I moved this amendment - of course, I knew it will be the next Assembly that will fix the salaries of the Ministers - it was just to initiate a discussion and to give a warning to the incoming Assembly. The reason is this -

    The Chairman: Order. I think I did make it quite clear that there cannot be a debate on the salaries as such. A debate on that can take place in the Estimates Committee. We are now on the policy of the Government covered by the Chief Minister's Ministry.
